result.execSummary:
The defendant Lukas W Olson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of THC, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Payable at the rate of $100.00 per month, starting on or before September 1, 2016 and on the same day each month thereafter, until paid in full.    Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.  $15.00 payment plan fee added.  Bond on file applied to the fine and court costs.
Defendant may apply for expungement 1 year after financial obligations in this case and 16TR692 are paid in full, and the defendant has no other criminal charges.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Lukas W Olson

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody with Attorney Poss.  Victim notification complied with.   Plead no contest to Count 2 in 16CF30 and 16TR692. Dismiss, but read in remaining charges in 16CF30.  Court recited the charges and possible penalties on the counts he plead to.   Defendant understood.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the pleas.  Found guilty of Possession of THC, contrary to 961.41(3g)(e).   Joint recommendation for:  $50.00 plus costs.  DNA sample.  May apply for expungment 1 year after all financial obligations have been satisfied.  Defendant did not exercise his right to allocution.   Court ordered:  $50.00 plus costs.  DNA sample.  May apply for expungment 1 year after financial obligations have been satisfied and have no further criminal charges.  Pay both fines @ $100/mo starting 9/1.
Plea/sentencing hearing on August 1, 2016 at 10:00 am.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Poss.  Discharge summary given to State today.  Successfully completed.  Set for plea with JA.  Need to waive preliminary also.  TR ticket.  Reopen and track.

Status conference rescheduled per agr between Atty Poss and DA Fox to give the defendant an opportunity to complete treatment program before case resolved. Request made via emails from Atty Poss and DA Fox.
Status conference on July 11, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

Pre-trial conference at 03-23-2016 10:00 am.
Status conference at 04-11-2016 03:00 pm.

Court questioned the defendant on his understanding of the waiver of time limits.  Defendant stated he understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his time limits for preliminary hearing.
records.descr: Waiver of time limits for preliminary hearing

records.addlTxt: DA Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Diehn.  Reading of the complaint waived.  PTC 3/23 and STC 4/11 at 3 pm.  Bond continued.  Defendant does not need to be in court for the 4/11 STC.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Provide saliva or UA sample upon demand from any law enforcement officer.

Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Provide saliva or UA sample upon demand from any law enforcement officer.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared by video from the Jackson County Jail.  No counsel present.  Court advised the charges and possible penalties contained in the complaint.  Defendant understood.  Defendant contacted SPD.  He is eligible.  AIA 2/29/16 at 9 am.
